A nonconducting block is sliding to the right across a rough horizontal surface within a region that contains a uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> that is directed out of the page. The nonconducting block has mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"> <mi>M</mi> </math> and has a net positive charge <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math> distributed uniformly throughout its volume. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mi>μ</mi></math>, and at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> the velocity of the block is <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> in the <math alttext="positive x" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></math>-direction, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.
